block.p: Worst Fighting in 4 Years Explodes in West Bank Israeli and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank as violent protests swept through Palestinian enclaves. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won approval from Parliament to cede three villages to the Palestinian Authority, which was originally intended by Mr. Barak as a gesture of good will to advance the peace talks.

Ethiopia-Eritrea Border War Eritrea said it had shot down two Ethiopian aircraft and inflicted heavy casualties in intense fighting. Ethiopia conceded that a helicopter had been downed but denied that it had also lost a fighter.

Worst Fighting in 4 Years Explodes in West Bank Israeli and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank as violent protests swept through Palestinian enclaves. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won approval from Parliament to cede three villages to the Palestinian Authority, which was originally intended by Mr. Barak as a gesture of good will to advance the peace talks.

Ethiopia-Eritrea Border War Eritrea said it had shot down two Ethiopian aircraft and inflicted heavy casualties in intense fighting. Ethiopia conceded that a helicopter had been downed but denied that it had also lost a fighter.

The United States asked the Security Council to impose sanctions on Ethiopia and Eritrea until the border fighting stopped. The resolution would prohibit the sale or delivery of weapons and military equipment to either side, and would bar senior Ethiopian officials from international travel. But the proposal has met resistance on the Security Council.

Leaning Toward China Bill Representative Charles B. Rangel, an influential senior House Democrat from New York, signaled that he was leaning in favor of the China trade bill. Heavy lobbying is expected to lead up to next week's scheduled vote.

Assessing Kosovo Prospects The General Accounting Office said prospects for lasting peace in Kosovo, Bosnia and other parts of the Balkans remained bleak, and it warned of the prospect of instability and even renewed violence. The report was issued on the eve of a Senate vote to set a deadline for withdrawing American troops.

Defending Massacre Report The Associated Press presented detailed evidence to rebut critics of its Pulitzer Prize-winning news report that said American soldiers, acting under orders, killed hundreds of South Korean civilians in the early days of the Korean War.

Hostage Incident in Norway A man armed with a shotgun and bitter at losing custody of his children held up to 35 children and adults hostage for about 11 hours in a kindergarten in Hjelmeland, in western Norway. He surrendered.

Court Voids Key Provision Of Law to Protect Women The Supreme Court, ruling 5 to 4, invalidated a provision of the six-year-old Violence Against Women Act that had let victims of rape, domestic violence and other crimes ''motivated by gender'' sue their attackers in federal court. A provision making it a federal crime to cross state lines to commit an act of domestic violence or stalking is not affected.

Bush Stakes Out Early Lead Gov. George W. Bush has emerged at this early stage as the preferred candidate across the demographic spectrum, a New York Times/CBS News Poll found, with Americans preferring him personally to Vice President Al Gore, though Mr. Gore's issue positions are more appealing.
Governor Bush proposed letting workers choose how to invest some of their Social Security taxes.

New Coalition on Immigration Jack Kemp, left, a former Republican vice presidential candidate, and Henry G. Cisneros, a former housing secretary, will head a coalition of conservatives and liberals seeking an easing of immigration laws.

A panel of scientists and engineers who advise the government expressed concern that heightened security measures at federal laboratories appeared to be damaging the ability to hire and retain foreign-born and minority scientists.
A Plan to Bomb the Moon Air Force scientists worked on a cold-war plan to detonate a nuclear bomb on the moon as a show of strength, a physicist said.
Indian Sites Imperiled by Fire The Los Alamos wildfire threatened ancient Indian dwellings and lands in New Mexico that contain invaluable archaeological sites.

Report on Columbine Rampage The 13 people shot to death at Columbine High School were all assaulted within the first 16 minutes as the authorities were assessing the situation outside, a sheriff's report said.
Wire Service Is Sold U.P.I., which has struggled for years with red ink and a succession of owners, has been bought by the affiliate of the Unification Church that publishes The Washington Times.

Mayor Leaning Toward Run; G.O.P. Wants Final Answer Mayor Giuliani raised money for his Senate campaign at an evening event, saying, ''I'm very much inclined to do this.'' Earlier, he continued to say he had not yet decided whether to run. Republicans reacted with growing exasperation.

Tough Reply to Rights Panel The New York Police Department says in response to a draft report by the United States Civil Rights Commission that the panel's research was slipshod and its conclusion that the police engage in racial profiling was recklessly unfair.

Some Gaps in Picket Line The Museum of Modern Art said 40 percent of the 250 workers in the union had returned to work in the 18-day strike. The union president said the strike was still going strong.

Giving the Space Station a Lift The International Space Station, under construction about 200 miles up, is losing altitude every day. The shuttle Atlantis, set to be launched on Thursday, will try to nudge it up 20 miles or so to ensure it does not fall to Earth before it is completed.
Hooked on Online Sex A new psychological disorder -- cybersex addiction -- appears to be rapidly spreading and roiling the lives of those affected.
Clot-Busting Drugs Questioned Three studies challenge the safety and benefits of clot-busting drugs for older people suffering heart attacks, particularly those 75 and older.
Bob Knight's Punishment The Indiana basketball coach was suspended for three games next season and fined $30,000 for what a university inquiry concluded was his ''pattern of inappropriate behavior.''

A Multinational Online Deal Lycos, one of the nation's biggest Internet portals, was said to have agreed to be acquired by the Net arm of Telefonica of Spain in a deal that would also involve Bertelsmann and be worth more than $12 billion.

Stocks Up on Eve of Fed Meeting The Dow rose 198.41 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,807.78; the Nasdaq climbed 78.59, or 2.2 percent, to 3,607.65; and the S.& P. 500 jumped 31.40, or 2.2 percent, to 1,452.36. The Fed is expected to raise rates by half a percentage point today.
Interest rose in Nabisco Holdings and its parent, the Nabisco Group.
Rodman C. Rockefeller The oldest son of Nelson A. Rockefeller was 68. He was active in efforts that led to Nafta.
Editorials: Violence against the Constitution; closing the achievement gap; ruinous war in the Horn of Africa; a coach beyond punishment.
